channel.title: Proxy Server (With Other Features)
channel.description:
Well, I spent my free time on this small little project. Turned out to be quite nice, and I like it. Anyways, here's the scoop.
This is a proxy server (obviously written in Java), that I wrote up to learn and get used to the [i]java.nio[/i] packaged provided in the Java API.
But the fun thing about it is that I added a few additional/bonus features.
[ul][li]Host name filter (parses and blocks names using regex)[/li] [li]Display any page you want (I used this to display a 'host name blocked' page and 'host name not found' page)[/li] [li]HTML source encoding (optional) (my favorite feature - it is also enabled when you download the JAR but by default it is disabled)[/li][/ul]
And for a list of known bugs to slow down any complaints:
[ul][li]When using the encode HTML feature, the response to the client may be slow (but it's fast enough to keep you from dieing and worth it if at work/school).[/li] [li]When using the encode HTML feature, and if the header contains a 'Transfer-Encoding: chunked' field, the 'chunked' data headers in the HTML source code may be left there when the page is displayed.[/li][/ul]
The only real big downsides to this are that the encode HTML feature can be a little slow at times (seems to work very well on MSCP/MITB for some reason), and that this server is currently on a 'thread-per-client' set up. Yes, I know it's bad. But I have no real intentions to create a huge server out of this, and using a thread-per-client set up to learn and use NIO was good enough for me at the time.
The encoding works using JavaScript. If the client has JS disabled, the page will not display and a </noscript> string will be displayed instead. It works by taking advantage of the unescape() method that comes with the version of JS. It will 'escape' each character in the HTML source to it's hexadecimal counterpart and append a '%' in front of it. Using this can render any content filters that work by keyword, especially at school or at work, useless.
And of course, there are credits:
[ul][li]Zachera - Led me to a great website explaining how to encode your HTML source code. (For anybody curious about that, the link is: http://scriptasylum.com/tutorials/encdec/encode-decode.html - I also forgot to mention I ONLY added the escaping part.)[/li] [li]Taharok - Helped me out on a few parts here and there and brought in the idea of encoding.[/li][/ul]
I've uploaded the JAR archive (source only - you can compile it) as an attachment here. There is a total of only four classes, named Buffer, Filter, Server, and Session.
Enjoy and PLEASE leave appropriate comments/constructive criticism/other helpful tips for the future when using NIO or for any general programming purpose. The mentioning of any bugs would be great, too!
P.S. I named the archive JProxy as I couldn't think of a better one at the time. :)
P.S.S. I know MINA exists. No need for criticism on that.

item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie

@pizza_pie wrote:

Umm… if you run it on ComputerA and connect to ComputerA’s set IP and PORT as the proxy server from ComputerB, then it will appear as if you have ComputerA’s IP, so yes.

item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:27, topic:213604”]Lol answer to my question plz?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 03, 2008, 05:17:35 pm[/size][hr][quote author=pizza pie link=topic=281139.msg2471460#msg2471460 date=1223005688]
hey I’m rly sry to bring up an old topic like this… but i waited until the beggining of the school year to start working on this but i get an error right away: i cannot connect to any site:

[***.***.*.*] HOST NOT FOUND : image/gif, image/x-xbitmap, image/jpg, image/pjpeg, application/vnd.ms-excel, aplication/vnd.ms-powerpoint, application/smword, application/x-silverlight, application/x-silverlight-2-b2m application/x-shockwave-flash, */*

Blocked out my IP

Also, on Internet explorer, I got Tools > Internet Options > Connections tab > LAN Settings and set the proxy ip to my ip and the port to 8080, the default. I’m planning on leaving on this on my home computer and connnecting to at school. So, explain error plz?
[/quote][/quote]Figure it out yourself. This is old stuff, and now that I look back at it, poorly written.

Read full topic

item.title: Proxy Server (With Other Features)
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:11, topic:213604”]You can set an argument final too, so you don’t need to declare a final temporary variable in order to use it in the inner class:

private void startProxySession(SocketChannel sockChan) { final Server thisServ = this; final SocketChannel tempSock = sockChan; new Thread() { public void run() { try { Session theUser = new Session(thisServ, ourFilter, tempSock);
->

private void startProxySession(final SocketChannel sockChan) { final Server thisServ = this; new Thread() { public void run() { try { Session theUser = new Session(thisServ, ourFilter, sockChan);[/quote]
instead of using thisServ, you could just do

Session theUser = new Session(Server.this, ourFilter, sockChan);

Read full topic

item.title: Proxy Server (With Other Features)
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

sanga282:

Are you testing him or generally wanting to know?

i generally wanted to know,

especially about the NIO/IO part,
since i wrote that peer-to-peer-chat program with IO, im interested in the whole networking stuff,
although i used inputstream.available() so it behaves in a non-blocking way, and you can have one thread check all connections,

ThAt0n36Uy:

Does it matter? yakman is the Java Guru.

thats not the desired attitude, where you believe anything anyone says if they are “important”
you should question what people say, regardless of if they are prince or pauper,

its this kind of elitist attitude that makes religion spread in society, people say
“well this guy is saying absolutely ridiculous things, but since he is important, I’m going to believe him”

Read full topic

item.title: Proxy Server (With Other Features)
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:8, topic:213604”][quote author=pizza pie link=topic=281139.msg2284852#msg2284852 date=1213864685]
I’m sure I won’t learn much looking through your source.
[/quote]

yes you will,

so telenubby, did you use an already existing protocol like SOCKS5, or your own invention?
also, what are the advantages or javas NIO compaired to IO?[/quote]
No. Not anything of my own creation. I personally did not have to work with any protocol other than HTTP. Yet I still feel that question was just a dumb response regarding one or more of my previous posts. I’m not really sure to any advantages for using NIO, my guess would be the ability to work with a non-blocking socket? But I have also heard that NIO is in fact a little slower than the older IO package and it can be a little unstable/buggy at times because it is still fairly new(?).

[quote=“k00dr, post:11, topic:213604”]First of all, let me congratulate you. The code looks clear and stylish
Then, here’s a few things to fix (not performance-wise…)

Selector.selectedKeys() is type Set, so you can use those generics properly:
(you could also use the for-each loop instead of manual iteration)

You can set an argument final too, so you don’t need to declare a final temporary variable in order to use it in the inner class.

You know System.arraycopy! Why not use it?

Duplicate method, Buffer.getBytes(ByteBuffer) and Session.getBytes(ByteBuffer).

Also, you should definitely register the SocketChannels for reading and writing in the Selector, drop the one-thread-per-client model and design it well :)[/quote]
Thanks for the great response, it was just what I was hoping for! I did not notice your first suggestion (regarding the generics) when programming it the first time, as I was simply learning from examples across the net. As for your second regarding the final modifier, I did not notice that either and most likely forgot about it. The System.arraycopy() part I knew about, and did try to use it earlier. I remember getting some sort of heap space error as well, and instead of fixing it properly I was lazy and wrote my own version of it. But I know arraycopy() is native and is much faster than what I wrote. I did know about the duplicate method getBytes(ByteBuffer) but again, I just left it how it was. Thanks again for the great reply.

nueb35:

nice, ive been tryng to make something like this all school year… looks good.

Yep. Thanks. How far did you end up getting, and did you use the IO or NIO package?

Read full topic

item.title: Proxy Server (With Other Features)
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

First of all, let me congratulate you. The code looks clear and stylish
Then, here’s a few things to fix (not performance-wise…)

Selector.selectedKeys() is type Set, so you can use those generics properly:
(you could also use the for-each loop instead of manual iteration)

Iterator<?> sockIt = sockSelect.selectedKeys().iterator(); while(sockIt.hasNext()) { SelectionKey sockKey = (SelectionKey)sockIt.next();
->

Iterator<SelectionKey> sockIt = sockSelect.selectedKeys().iterator(); while(sockIt.hasNext()) { SelectionKey sockKey = sockIt.next();

You can set an argument final too, so you don’t need to declare a final temporary variable in order to use it in the inner class:

private void startProxySession(SocketChannel sockChan) { final Server thisServ = this; final SocketChannel tempSock = sockChan; new Thread() { public void run() { try { Session theUser = new Session(thisServ, ourFilter, tempSock);
->

private void startProxySession(final SocketChannel sockChan) { final Server thisServ = this; new Thread() { public void run() { try { Session theUser = new Session(thisServ, ourFilter, sockChan);

You know System.arraycopy! Why not use it?

private byte[] combine(byte[] origSet, byte[] appendSet) { int currentIdx = 0; byte[] newBytes = new byte[origSet.length + appendSet.length]; for(byte b : origSet) newBytes[currentIdx++] = b; for(byte bb : appendSet) newBytes[currentIdx++] = bb; return newBytes; }
->

private byte[] combine(byte[] a, byte[] b) { byte[] newArray = new byte[a.length + b.length]; System.arraycopy(a, 0, newArray, 0, a.length); System.arraycopy(b, 0, newArray, a.length, b.length); return newArray; }

Duplicate method, Buffer.getBytes(ByteBuffer) and Session.getBytes(ByteBuffer).

Also, you should definitely register the SocketChannels for reading and writing in the Selector, drop the one-thread-per-client model and design it well

Read full topic
